_comment: The tools listed here are defined at compile time and serve
You may include additional CTF tools to extend the available options and
customize the environment to your needs.

cyberchef.name: CyberChef
cyberchef.description: "The Cyber Swiss Army Knife" - a web app for encryption, encoding, compression and data analysis. It allows for building complex data processing "recipes" to decode, deobfuscate, or transform data in CTF challenges.

exiftool.name: ExifTool
exiftool.description: A command-line utility for reading, writing, and editing meta information in a wide variety of files. In CTFs, it's used to find hidden data, GPS coordinates, or other clues in file metadata.

binwalk.name: Binwalk
binwalk.description: A tool for analyzing and extracting firmware images and binary files. It's essential in forensics and reversing challenges to find hidden files, file systems, or embedded code within a larger file.

zsteg.name: zsteg
zsteg.description: A steganography tool that detects hidden data in PNG and BMP images. It can find data hidden in least-significant bits (LSB) and other techniques.

stegseek.name: StegSeek
stegseek.description: A very fast steganography tool for seeking hidden data inside files. It's particularly effective for brute-forcing steghide passwords on JPG files, making it a go-to for certain steganography challenges.

hashcat.name: hashcat
hashcat.description: A powerful and fast password recovery tool. In CTFs, it's used to crack password hashes obtained from various sources like password files, databases, or network captures.

john.name: John the Ripper
john.description: A popular password cracking tool. It can automatically detect the hash type and use various methods like dictionary attacks, brute-force, and rainbow tables to crack them. Often used as an alternative or in conjunction with hashcat.
